data.title: 'BrainDead,' starring Mary Elizabeth Winstead, now on DVD (review)
data.meta_description: Other recent home-video releases include "Jason Bourne" and "Don't Think Twice."
data.text:
BrainDead

This ambitious CBS series, cancelled after one season in June, deserved more time for viewers to find it. An unusual combination of political satire and science fiction, it involves mind-controlling space insects. They invade Washington, D.C., taking over anyone whose brain they can crawl inside, including top politicians. The joke is that in today's divisive capital, no one can tell. Mary Elizabeth Winstead, a "scream queen" in "10 Cloverfield Lane" and "The Thing," shows a deft comedic touch in the lead. She's an out-of-work documentary filmmaker moving back home to work for her brother, a U.S. senator (Danny Pino). As the 2016 presidential campaign rages in the background, she senses something is very wrong. Unrated, 13 episodes, 561 minutes. Extras: three featurettes and a gag reel. From Paramount. Released Dec. 6 on DVD.

Jason Bourne

Matt Damon took a nine-year break from playing memory-challenged CIA assassin Jason Bourne, but he hasn't forgotten what it takes to make an exciting spy thriller. Bourne is hiding out because he knows his former bosses want him taken out. So he keeps a low profile, fighting in underground bare-fisted matches to make money. A former colleague (Julia Stiles) pulls him back into the fray when she brings him new evidence about his family's involvement in the program. Tommy Lee Jones, Alicia Vikander and Vincent Cassel star in the July release, which hopscotches from Greece to Iceland to Virginia and other exotic locales. This is director Paul Greengrass' third "Bourne" outing. PG-13. From Universal Pictures Home Entertainment. Released Dec. 6. Also released Dec. 6 is a six-disc set with all five "Bourne" films, called "The Bourne Ultimate Collection."

Don't Think Twice

A six-member improv comedy team toils for years together only to have their cozy group dynamic threatened when one of them is cast in a network sketch comedy show resembling "Saturday Night Live." What happens to the rest of them now that one member is rocketing to solo stardom? Will the others ever get their big break? This bright comedy from July stars Keegan-Michael Key, Gillian Jacobs and Mike Birbiglia, who also wrote and directed. Rated R, 92 minutes. From Universal Pictures Home Entertainment.

Mad Max High Octane Collection

All four "Mad Max" films are assembled in this eight-disc Blu-ray set, the first three starring Mel Gibson. The most recent film in the franchise, 2015's "Mad Max: Fury Road," is also presented in a stunning 4K Ultra HD edition. From Fox. Released Dec. 6.

Shannara Chronicles, season one

Elves, druids, trolls and the occasional human interact in this science-fiction fantasy series from New Zealand, set in the distant future. Released on DVD in June, it makes its Blu-ray debut. From Paramount. Released Dec. 6.

The T.A.M.I. Show and The Big T.N.T. Show

Not one but two seminal rock concert films from the mid-1960s make their Blu-ray debuts in this combo collector's edition. Performers include the Rolling Stones, James Brown, the Beach Boys, Ike and Tina Turner, The Byrds, Smokey Robinson and the Miracles, Chuck Berry, the Ronettes and Ray Charles. Extras include a 36-page booklet. From Shout Select. Released Dec. 6.

The Secret Agent

The ever-busy Toby Jones stars as a Russian spy disguised as a lowly Soho shopkeeper in Victorian England in this three-part BBC series based on Joseph Conrad's 1907 novel. Vicky McClure, Stephen Graham and Ian Hart co-star. From Acorn Media. Released Dec. 6.

Kicks

After working hard and saving up money to buy new Air Jordan sneakers, Brandon, 15, loses his treasured footwear to a local thief. With the help of two friends, he dares to try to get them back. Jahking Guillory plays the young hero in this adventure from September set in the East Bay section of Oakland, California, where having the right shoes means everything to kids. From Universal Pictures Home Entertainment. Released Dec. 6 on DVD and Blu-ray.

The Hollars

John Krasinski of "The Office" stars in and directs this romantic comedy-drama from August about a big-city artist back in his small-town home because a family member has fallen ill. The great cast includes Sharlto Copley, Richard Jenkins, Anna Kendrick and Margo Martindale. From Sony Pictures Home Entertainment. Released Dec. 6.

Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer

The controversial 1986 horror crime film, shot on 16mm in 28 days in 1986 for $110,000, gets a 30th anniversary Blu-ray makeover. Director John McNaughton's debut, loosely based on a serial killer portrayed by Michael Rooker, is presented in a new 4K scan. It's taken from the original camera negative and features a new 5.1 restoration mix from the 35mm mag reels. For those who have no idea what that means, the picture looks a lot cleaner and crisper than ever before. From Dark Sky Films. Released Dec. 6.

The Quiet Earth

A man wakes up to discover he appears to be the last man on Earth in this 1985 science-fiction mystery. Bruno Lawrence stars as a scientist working on a global energy project that malfunctions, making him suspect that it may be why all humans and animals have disappeared, except for himself. But why is every clock he finds set at 6:12? The eerie New Zealand film won 10 awards. From Film Movement. Released Dec. 6 on Blu-ray.

I am Bolt

Usain Bolt, the fastest man on Earth, tells his story in this upbeat 2016 sports biodoc. Famous people interviewed include Serena Williams, Pele, Neymar, Ziggy Marley and Nas. From Universal Pictures Home Entertainment. Released Dec. 6 on DVD.

Zoo, season two

After centuries of being pushovers for their human masters, animals around the world suddenly are fighting back in this CBS science-fiction drama series. It stars James Wolk as a zoologist trying to figure out what the heck is going on. The second season debuted in June. From Paramount. Released Dec. 6 on DVD.

The Secret Life of Pets

When the humans are away, the pets do play, demonstrates this family-friendly animated comedy from July. The voice cast includes Louis C.K., Kevin Hart, Lake Bell, Dana Carvey, Albert Brooks and Steve Coogan. From Universal Picture Home Entertainment. Released Dec. 6 on DVD and Blu-ray.

If There's a Hell Below

Conner Marx stars as a muckraking young reporter for a Chicago independent newspaper who is offered a scoop from a mysterious corporate whistleblower. This unsatisfying suspense drama arrived in theaters in January and quickly evaporated. From Dark Sky Films. Released Dec. 6 on DVD.

Email Chris Ball at cball@plaind.com

On Twitter @ChrisBall99
